newsitem.title: UK: UK's Major gets tough over EU work week law.
newsitem.headline: UK's Major gets tough over EU work week law.

text.p: Britain headed for a new showdown with its European Union partners on Tuesday, threatening to veto reforms crucial for the bloc's expansion unless they agreed to overturn a law limiting the EU working week to 48 hours.

Prime Minister John Major fired off a letter to European Commisssion President Jacques Santer and fellow EU leaders minutes after the European Court of Justice (ECJ) ruled that Britain must obey the controversial Working Time Directive.

Major said introduction of laws that would fetter Britain's flexible labour market was counter to the spirit of the opt-out he won from Social Chapter legislation during negotiations on the Maastricht treaty on economic and political union in 1991.
"It is unacceptable and must be remedied," Major wrote.

He said he would demand treaty changes at the Inter- Governmental Conference (IGC), due to end next year, which is discussing how to adapt the EU's institutions so the 15-nation bloc can expand to take in new members from eastern Europe.
Major said he would use his veto to block a conclusion to the IGC unless the Maastricht treaty was amended to prevent workplace laws being introduced "through the back door".

"I do not see how new agreements can be reached if earlier agreements are being undermined," Major, who brought EU business to a virtual standstill for several weeks earlier this year in a row over mad cow disease, told his fellow leaders.

The ECJ ruled that Britain must comply with the working time directive because the Commission had been right to introduce it under European health and safety provisions, which allowed Britain to be outvoted by its European partners.
Britain had appealed to the Luxembourg court, arguing that the issue has nothing to do with health and safety.
EU Social Affairs Commissioner Padraig Flynn criticised Britain for "threatening to hold the IGC to ransom" and defended the directive as an essential health and safety measure.

Trade and Industry Secretary Ian Lang said it could cost British industry as much as two billion pounds ($3.31 billion) a year to implement the directive, which also guarantees rest periods and holidays.
But trade unions saluted the ruling and the TUC umbrella body said three affiliated unions were preparing test cases in the event of the government refusing to implement the directive.
The issue could become a big factor in Britain's general election, due by May, because it crystalises differences between the ruling Conservatives and the main opposition Labour party.

Major plans to fight for re-election on the claim that he has turned Britain into the "enterprise centre of Europe", cutting unemployment and attracting the lion's share of foreign investment into the EU, thanks to its deregulated job market.
"I would like British people back in work, not debarred from work because of the raft of legislation that makes it too expensive or too difficult to employ them," he told reporters.
Labour, by contrast, though it has moved closer to the Conservatives on many aspects of European policy, strongly backs the 48-hour week and would sign the Social Chapter.
Labour accused Major of indulging in "diplomacy of the playground" in threatening to block the outcome of the IGC.

"It is artificial indignation from a government that is... trying to use what are very modest measures to protect the rights of the individual in a way that they hope will create an anti-European feeling," employment spokesman David Blunkett said.
A group of eight "Euro-sceptic" Conservatives duly condemned the ECJ ruling as a "constitutional outrage" that could plunge Britain into "the nightmare of high unemployment".
